title: Former National Museum of Australia director Andrew Sayers dies
text:
Andrew Sayers died in his Melbourne home after a battle with pancreatic cancer. Photo: Simon O'Dwyer 
Former National Museum Australia director Andrew Sayers has died.
Sayers, who also directed the National Portrait Gallery, was battling pancreatic cancer.
He died at his Melbourne home Sunday night. He was 58.
Andrew Sayers died after a battle with pancreatic cancer. Photo: Simon O'Dwyer 
Sayers left his position at the National Museum in July 2013, just three years into a five-year appointment.
Advertisement After vacating the director's chair for deputy director Mathew Trinca, Sayers turned to his first love: painting.
Sayers entered a daring nude self-portrait in the Doug Moran National Portrait Prize last year and showcased some of his landscapes and beach scenes in Bermagui on the NSW South Coast.
Corunna Point by Andrew Sayers, who developed his love for Australian landscapes growing up in northern Sydney.
His portrait of environmental lawyer and cultural historian Tim Bonyhady was selected as a finalist in the 2015 Archibald Prize .
Sayers was the inaugural director of the National Portrait Gallery for more than a decade from 1998 to 2010.
Earlier, he was curator and assistant director of collections at the National Gallery of Australia from 1985 to 1998.
self-portrait by Andrew Sayers.
Sayers was born in England and arrived in Sydney in 1964 with his family at seven years of age.
He was raised in the rugged bushland of Sydney's northern fringe where he developed a love for Australia's landscape.
After university, where he decided he'd rather curate than paint, Sayers landed a job at the Art Gallery of NSW.
Andrew Sayers' portrait of Tim Bonyhady. Photo: AGNSW/Mim Stirling 
In 2010 he was appointed a Member of the Order of Australia for services to arts administration.
Three years later he moved to Melbourne to join his wife, Perry, and set up a studio in Richmond.
Sayers had been making art since he was a child, but had always strived to keep his practice private.
"In every house that we've ever lived in, I've had a studio, and I've been painting and drawing," he previously said. "I've always found time to paint and draw."
An exhibition of his new paintings and works on paper was due to open at Canberra's Beaver Galleries on November 5.
Earlier this year Sayers said his cancer was "the background static of my life" .
"But the diagnosis has made me fearless. Before it, I would have waited another year or two before showing anyone my paintings. Now I just say 'this is me'."
Sayers' family will gather for a small private funeral in the near future.
His life will be celebrated publicly in the coming months as part of a Canberra-based event.
Sayers' family asked for donations to the Four Winds Festival or Kosciuszko Huts Association in lieu of flowers.
More to come.
